Three new species of Labomimus Sharp (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Pselaphinae) from Taiwan, China, with an updated key for L. Shibatai Sawada-group
Article
Full-text available
  • Apr 2019
  • YU-QING ZHANG
  • Zi-Wei Yin
The Labomimus Sharp fauna in Taiwan is represented by a single species. In this paper, three new species are described and illustrated: L. dadongmontis sp. nov., L. dilaticeps sp. nov., and L. sugayai sp. nov. The key to species of the L. shibatai Sawada-group is updated to accommodate the two new species placed in this group.

The monotypic genus Chandleriella Hlaváč, 2000 is reported from China for the first time, and a new species, C. yunnanica Yin, sp. nov. (type locality: Lincang, Yunnan), is described.   • Feb 2019
  • Chenyang Cai
  • Dave Clarke
  • Zi-Wei Yin
  • [...]
  • Diying Huang
Cai et al. report specialized prey-capture structures in two species of the stenine rove beetles from mid-Cretaceous Burmese amber. The discovery provides critical information about the origin and early evolution of both the novel predatory structure and of the subfamily Steninae (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae).

Projects

Projects (3)
Systematics and evolution of the ant-loving beetles (Staphylinidae: Pselaphinae)
Project
I (together with students and co-workers) am interested in documenting the extant diversity of the large rove beetle subfamily Pselaphinae (mainly from Asia), and using fossils to understand their evolutionary history.
View
Paleontology of amber fossils
Project
We are working on beetle fossils of Dominican, Baltic, and Burmese ambers. Our main goal is easy; publish them as possible as we can. If we could try phylogenetic analyses, then we will try to elucidate a fossil's systematic position. Collaboration with me (Shuhei Yamamoto) is welcome in most cases.
View
Beetles in deep time and more
Project
1. Fossil Beetles. Mesozoic beetles (Coleoptera) from the Middle Jurassic Daohugou biota (ca. 165 Ma), the Early Cretaceous Jehol biota (ca. 125 Ma) of northeastern China and the mid-Cretaceous Burmese amber (ca. 99 Ma): Systematics, phylogeny, biogeography and palaeoethology. Studied groups include Archostemata (Ommatidae), Myxophaga (Hydroscaphidae) and the hyper-diverse Polyphaga (Derodontidae, Jacobsoniidae, Silphidae, Smicripidae, Staphylinidae, Tetratomidae, etc.); 2. Subsocial Behavior in Fossil Insects. Early evolution of parental care in Mesozoic carrion beetles (Silphidae); 3. Palaeobiota in Amber. Morphology, systematics, biogeography and complex behavior of insects in Cretaceous Burmese amber
